message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of DVT and presents with shortness of breath and chest pain, which suggests the possibility of pulmonary embolism. In this case, pericardial effusion may also be present, leading to electrical alternans on the ECG. Increased QT interval is seen in patients with electrolyte abnormalities and certain medications. Deep Q wave is seen in patients with a history of myocardial infarction. S1Q3T3 pattern can be seen in pulmonary embolism but is not as specific as electrical alternans.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests pulmonary embolism, which can cause right heart strain and electrical alternans on the ECG. The other options are less commonly seen in pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of pulmonary embolism, which can cause electrical alternans on the ECG. None of the other options are specifically associated with pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of pulmonary embolism with shortness of breath and chest pain, and he also has a history of deep vein thrombosis. The ECG changes associated with pulmonary embolism include electric alternans, specifically alternation of QRS amplitude or axis. The other options are not associated with pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest he may have pulmonary embolism. The pale conjunctiva may indicate anemia, and the tenderness in the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints suggest he may have rheumatoid arthritis. Anti-SM-1 antibodies being positive confirms a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which may lead to pulmonary embolism. Electric alternans on ECG indicates pericardial effusion, which can occur in SLE. None of the other options are associated with pulmonary embolism or SLE.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and lab results suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. Electric alternans, which is a variation of QRS amplitude, is a classic finding on ECG in cases of pericardial effusion and can be seen in cases of pulmonary embolism. The other options are not associated with pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, pulmonary embolism is a possibility. Electric alternans, or alternating amplitude of the QRS complexes on ECG, can be a sign of pericardial effusion caused by a pulmonary embolism. The other options are not typically associated with pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of pulmonary embolism (chest pain, shortness of breath, previous history of DVT) and laboratory studies show antiphospholipid syndrome (positive anti-SM-1 antibodies and high ANA titer). Electric alternans can be seen on ECG in cases of pulmonary embolism, and it is the most likely finding in this patient. Increased QT interval is seen in electrolyte imbalances and certain medications. Deep Q wave is seen in myocardial infarction. S1Q3T3 pattern is seen in acute right heart strain, which may occur with pulmonary embolism, but it is less specific than electric alternans.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can lead to pericarditis and cardiac tamponade. Electric alternans is a classic finding in patients with cardiac tamponade. The other options are not associated with SLE or cardiac tamponade.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible pulmonary embolism. An x-ray of the chest may not reveal anything significant, but an ECG may show electric alternans, which is a sign of pericardial effusion. The other options are not related to pulmonary embolism or pericardial effusion.
